this is my first time. i didnt know to use the app so just did the run and only pulled out the app at the end to find the person receiving. whoops!
The picture that is used to show the building is older. They have a blue sign next to the door now so I was confused if I had the right place.

Well, this was my first delivery to Cincinnati Union Bethel (CUB - Scholar House) and after a bit of an adventure, I found them and got the donation delivered.

Our app (and my own GOOGLE MAPS app) unerringly led me to 929 E. McMillan, but that address is for an art gallery. Our app's final delivery guidance note advised me to look for the destination around the side of the building, directly across from a CVS pharmacy.

Well, the day care center isn't around the corner from the art gallery, and there's no CVS pharmacy anywhere I could find, but a helpful lady at a side door of the building advised that the day care center is at the back of the building (just about directly opposite the art gallery) and she knew our contact and was able to guide me there. I was introduced to Laneisha there and she knew our contact (who had left well before I arrived) and she accepted the donation and signed off for it.

So 'All's Well That Ends Well' and so ends another minor Last Mile Food Rescue adventure!

The initial organization for drop off was not present and the lack of communication was unprofessional. But delivering to wayside was exponentially better than where we were supposed to go.

The place that I was supposed to go to, was closed and I drove far away to it and no one was there but I ended up getting to drop the donations off at wayside and seeing the faces of those we helped was amazing

One modest birthday cake sized box of non-nutricious pastries to a fire station in a rich town - I wholly agree that we need to help look after our emergency services people as we‚Äôd be lost without them, just don‚Äôt think this was in line with the vast majority of other rescues.

I'm not sure the hospital knows we are volunteers: a different employee helped this week and she acted like I should have a cart of my own and was offended when I explained that the last few weeks they just wheeled the car out to my car, exclaiming "YOU can wheel it to your car, but bring it back!" She was dressed in dress clothes, not their usual uniform so I think she was a manager. 

The recipients were wonderful, though! :) They brought extra people to help carry everything and were very happy to get protein this week!
Well, no donation, but it wasn't a total loss. I discovered they have a great cafeteria! (Not that I'm likely to ever have an opportunity to enjoy it, but it's still a nice one).
